crate_groups.name: Common
crate_groups.description: Very commonly used crates that everyone should know about

recommendations.name: rand
recommendations.notes: De facto standard random number generation library split out from the standard library

purposes.name: Time & Date
purposes.notes:
Unfortunately there is no clear answer as to which is best between time and chrono.
Evaluate for yourself between these two, but be resassured that both are trusted and well-maintained.

recommendations.name: time
recommendations.notes: A smaller, simpler library. Preferrable if covers your needs, but it's quite limited in what it provides.

recommendations.name: chrono
recommendations.notes: The most comphrehensive and full-featured datetime library, but more complex because of it.

recommendations.name: serde
recommendations.notes: De facto standard serialization library. Use in conjunction with sub-crates like serde_json for the specific format that you are using.

recommendations.name: regex
recommendations.notes: De facto standard regex library. Very fast, but does not support fancier features such as backtracking.

recommendations.name: fancy_regex
recommendations.notes: Use if need features such as backtracking which regex doesn't support

recommendations.name: uuid
recommendations.notes: Implements generating and parsing UUIDs and a number of utility functions

recommendations.name: tempfile
recommendations.notes: Supports both temporary files and temporary directories

recommendations.name: flate2
recommendations.notes: Uses a pure-Rust implementation by default. Use feature flags to opt in to system zlib.

recommendations.name: indexmap
recommendations.notes: A HashMap that seperately keeps track of insertion order and allows you to efficiently iterate over its elements in that order

recommendations.name: arrayvec
recommendations.notes: Arrays that are ONLY stack-allocated with fixed capacity

recommendations.name: smallvec
recommendations.notes: Arrays that are stack-allocated with fallback to the heap if the fixed stack capacity is exceeded

recommendations.name: tinyvec
recommendations.notes: Stack allocated arrays in 100% safe Rust code but requires items to implement the Default trait.

recommendations.name: reqwest
recommendations.notes: Full-fat HTTP client. Can be used in both synchronous and asynchronous code. Requires tokio runtime.

recommendations.name: ureq
recommendations.notes: Minimal synchronous HTTP client focussed on simplicity and minimising dependencies.

subgroups.name: Error Handling
subgroups.description: Crates for more easily handling errors

recommendations.name: anyhow
recommendations.notes: Provides a boxed error type that can hold any error, and helpers for generating an application-level stack trace.

recommendations.name: color-eyre
recommendations.notes: A fork of anyhow that gives you more control over the format of the generated error messages. Recommended if you need intend to present error messages to end users. Otherwise anyhow is simpler.

recommendations.name: thiserror
recommendations.notes: Helps with generating boilerplate for enum-style error types.

subgroups.name: Logging
subgroups.description: Crates for logging. Note that in general you will need a seperate crate for actually printing/storing the logs

recommendations.name: tracing
recommendations.notes: Tracing is now the go-to crate for logging.

recommendations.name: log
recommendations.notes: An older and simpler crate if your needs are simple and you are not using any async code.

recommendations.name: tracing
recommendations.notes: Tracing is now the go-to crate for logging.

recommendations.name: slog
recommendations.notes: Structured logging

subgroups.name: Language Extensions
subgroups.description: General purpose utility crates that extend language and/or stdlib functionality.

recommendations.name: once_cell
recommendations.notes: Newer crate with more ergonomic API. On track to be incorporated into the standard library. Should be preferred for all new projects.

recommendations.name: lazy_static
recommendations.notes: Older crate. API is less convenient, but crate is stable and maintained.

recommendations.name: itertools
recommendations.notes: A bunch of useful methods on iterators that aren't in the stdlib

recommendations.name: syn
recommendations.notes: Parse rust source code

recommendations.name: quote
recommendations.notes: Quasi quoting rust (useful for interpolating generated code with literal code)

recommendations.name: paste
recommendations.notes: Concatenating and manipulating identifiers

recommendations.name: num
recommendations.notes: Traits like Number, Add, etc that allow you write functions that are generic over the specific numeric type

recommendations.name: byteorder
recommendations.notes: Utility functions to convert between different endianness or read/write data with a specific endianness

recommendations.name: bitflags
recommendations.notes: Strongly typed bitflag types

subgroups.name: System
subgroups.description: For low-level interaction with the underling platform / operating system

recommendations.name: memmap2
recommendations.notes: The older memmap crate is unmaintained.

recommendations.name: libc
recommendations.notes: Bindings for directly calling libc functions.

recommendations.name: windows
recommendations.notes: The official Microsoft-provided crate for interacting with windows APIs

recommendations.name: winapi
recommendations.notes: Older binding to the windows APIs. Unofficial, but more complete than windows-rs

crate_groups.name: Cryptography
crate_groups.description: Crates that provide implementations of cryptographic algorithms. This section attempts to list the best crates for the listed algorithms, but does not intend to make recommendations for the algorithms themselves.

purposes.name: Password Hashing
purposes.notes: For more algorithms, see Rust Crypto Password Hashes.

purposes.name: General Purpose Hashing
purposes.notes: For more algorithms, see Rust Crypto Hashes.

purposes.name: AEAD Encryption
purposes.notes: For more algorithms, see Rust Crypto AEADs.

purposes.name: Digital Signatures
purposes.notes: For more algorithms, see Rust Crypto Signatures.

recommendations.name: ed25519
recommendations.notes: Use in conjunction with the ed25519-dalek crate.

purposes.name: Certificate Formats
purposes.notes: For more formats, see Rust Crypto Formats.

recommendations.name: rustls
recommendations.notes: A portable pure-rust high-level implementation of TLS. Implements TLS 1.2 and higher.

recommendations.name: native-tls
recommendations.notes: Delegates to the system TLS implementations on windows and macOS, and uses OpenSSL on linux.

recommendations.name: webpki
recommendations.notes: X.509 Certificate validation. Builds on top of ring.

recommendations.name: ring
recommendations.notes: Fork of BoringSSL. Provides cryptographic primitives for TLS/SSL

recommendations.name: subtle
recommendations.notes: Utilities for writing constant-time algorithms

recommendations.name: zeroize
recommendations.notes: Securely erase memory

crate_groups.name: Networking
crate_groups.description: TCP, HTTP, GRPc, etc. And the executors required to do asynchronous networking.

subgroups.name: Async Executors
subgroups.description: To do async programming using the async-await in Rust you need a runtime to execute drive your Futures.

recommendations.name: tokio
recommendations.notes: The oldest async runtime in the Rust ecosystem and still the most widely supported. Recommended for new projects.

recommendations.name: async-std
recommendations.notes: A newer option that is very similar to tokio. Its API more closely mirrors the std library, but it doesn't have as much traction as Tokio.

recommendations.name: glommio
recommendations.notes: Use if you need io_uring support. Still somewhat experimental but rapidly maturing.

subgroups.name: HTTP
subgroups.description: HTTP client and server libraries, as well as lower-level building blocks.

recommendations.name: http
recommendations.notes: The `http` crate doesn't actually contain an HTTP implementation. Just types and interfaces to help interoperability.

recommendations.name: hyper
recommendations.notes: A low-level HTTP implementation (both client and server). Implements HTTP 1, 2, and 3. Requires the tokio async runtime.

recommendations.name: reqwest
recommendations.notes: Full-fat HTTP client. Can be used in both synchronous and asynchronous code. Requires tokio runtime.

recommendations.name: ureq
recommendations.notes: Minimal synchronous HTTP client focussed on simplicity and minimising dependencies.

see_also.name: surf
see_also.notes: Client that uses the async-std runtime rather than the tokio runtime. Not well maintained.

recommendations.name: axum
recommendations.notes: A minimal and ergonomic framework. An official part of the tokio project. Recommend for most new projects.

recommendations.name: actix-web
recommendations.notes: A performance focussed framework. All Rust frameworks are fast, but choose actix-web if you need the absolutely maximum performance.

see_also.name: rocket
see_also.notes: Has an excellent API and a solid implementation. However development has been intermittent, and the async branch still doesn't have a stable release. Use of rocket is not recommended until this has fixed.

see_also.name: warp
see_also.notes: Very similar to axum but with a quirkier API. This is a solid framework, but you should probably prefer Axum unless you particular like the API

see_also.name: tide
see_also.notes: Similar to Axum, but based on async-std rather than tokio

recommendations.name: async-graphql
recommendations.notes: A high-performance graphql server library that's fully specification compliant. Integrates with actix-web, axum, poem, rocket, tide, warp.

subgroups.name: Websockets
subgroups.description: This section includes libraries for you to use just websockets. However note that many of the HTTP server frameworks in the section above also support websockets

recommendations.name: tungstenite-rs
recommendations.notes: Low-level crate that others build on

recommendations.name: tokio-tungstenite
recommendations.notes: If you are using the tokio executor

recommendations.name: async-tungstenite
recommendations.notes: If you are using the async-std executor

recommendations.name: tonic
recommendations.notes: gRPC over HTTP/2 with full support for asynchronous code. Works with tokio

recommendations.name: sqlx
recommendations.notes:
Works with Postgres, MySQL, SQLite, and MS SQL.
Supports compile time checking of queries. Async: supports both tokio and async-std.

recommendations.name: sea-orm
recommendations.notes: Recommended. Built on top of sqlx. There is also a related sea-query crate that provides a query builder without full ORM functionality.

recommendations.name: diesel
recommendations.notes: Stable release is sync only. Pre-release async branch is currently AGPL. Can provide better performance in some circumstances.

recommendations.name: tokio-postgres
recommendations.notes: Postgres-specific library. Performs better than SQLx

recommendations.name: mysql_async
recommendations.notes: Has a poorly designed API. Prefer SQLx for MySQL

recommendations.name: rustqlite
recommendations.notes: Provides a sync API to SQLite + provides access to advanced sqlite features.

recommendations.name: tiberius
recommendations.notes: MS SQL specific library. Has better support for advanced column types than SQLx.

recommendations.name: oracle
recommendations.notes: Rust bindings to ODPI-C

subgroups.name: Argument Parsing
subgroups.description: See argparse-benchmarks-rs for a full comparison of the crates mentioned here and more.

recommendations.name: bpaf
recommendations.notes: Generally recommended. Featureful, ergonomic and faster to compile than clap.

recommendations.name: clap
recommendations.notes: Ergonomic, includes the kitchen sink, and is fast at runtime. However compile times can be slow

recommendations.name: lexopt
recommendations.notes: Fast compile times, fast runtime, pedantic about correctness. API is less ergonomic

recommendations.name: pico-args
recommendations.notes: Fast compile times, fast runtime, more lax about correctness. API is more ergonomic

subgroups.name: Utility
subgroups.description: Helpers that are often useful when implementing CLIs

recommendations.name: globset
recommendations.notes: High-performance globbing that allows multiple globs to be evaluated at once

recommendations.name: walkdir
recommendations.notes: Basic recursive filesystem walking.

recommendations.name: ignore
recommendations.notes: Recursive filesystem walking that respects ignore files (like .gitignore)

recommendations.name: fs_extra
recommendations.notes: Recursively move, copy, and delete the files in a directory

recommendations.name: notify
recommendations.notes: Watch files or directories and execute a function when they change

subgroups.name: Terminal Rendering
subgroups.description: For fancy terminal rendering and TUIs. The crates recommended here work cross-platform (including windows).

recommendations.name: termcolor
recommendations.notes: Cross-platform terminal colour output

recommendations.name: indicatif
recommendations.notes: Progress bars and spinners

recommendations.name: crossterm
recommendations.notes: Cross-platform terminal rendering and event handling

recommendations.name: parking_lot
recommendations.notes: std::mutex also works fine. But Parking Lot is faster.

recommendations.name: arc_swap
recommendations.notes: Useful for sharing data that has many readers but few writers

purposes.name: Concurrent HashMap
purposes.notes: See conc-map-bench for comparative benchmarks of concurrent HashMaps.

recommendations.name: dashmap
recommendations.notes: The fastest for general purpose workloads

recommendations.name: flurry
recommendations.notes: Particularly good for read-heavy workloads.

purposes.name: Channels
purposes.notes: See communicating-between-sync-and-async-code for notes on when to use async-specific channels vs general purpose channels.

recommendations.name: crossbeam_channel
recommendations.notes: The absolute fastest channel implementation available. Implements Go-like 'select' feature.

recommendations.name: flume
recommendations.notes: Smaller and simpler than crossbeam_channel and almost as fast

recommendations.name: postage
recommendations.notes: Channels that integrate nicely with async code

recommendations.name: rayon
recommendations.notes: Convert sequential computation into parallel computation with one call - `par_iter` instead of `iter`
